head.title: Hospital Sets Its Sights On Pennsylvania

hedline.hl1: Hospital Sets Its Sights On Pennsylvania

abstract.p: Norm Goldman letter on March 25 editorial notes Capital Health System in Mercer County, NJ, wants to relocate hospital to Hopewell Township, near Pennsylvania border, and target Bucks County, Pa, residents

block.p: If I can't top them, at least I can add to ''Superfluous Hospitals'' (editorial, March 25).

Capital Health System in Mercer County, serving mostly the capital city of Trenton, is also in poor financial health, according to Standard & Poor's, the credit rating firm. If I can't top them, at least I can add to ''Superfluous Hospitals'' (editorial, March 25).

Capital Health System in Mercer County, serving mostly the capital city of Trenton, is also in poor financial health, according to Standard & Poor's, the credit rating firm. It wants to pull out of its major urban facility and relocate to the bucolic, sparsely populated Hopewell Township, bordering the Delaware River.
Capital Health System views it as a money-making move. Marketing will be targeted to residents of Bucks County, Pa., as a result of Route 95 access across the river.

New Jersey residents, who pay state income taxes to support hospitals, look with great suspicion at subsidizing Pennsylvania residents at a projected facility with private rooms and all the accouterments of a luxury hotel. It appears the state has to be more realistic and cost-effective as it focuses its fiscal support on existing viable hospitals serving the underserved population.
